Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)
Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)

result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (5th) and Operating w/ PAC (5th). The defendant was found guilty of both charges. Because Wisconsin law provides for only one penalty even if there is a conviction on both, no additional penalty has been imposed as a result of the second charge.

  • Randall K. Marquette was found guilty of OWI (5th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).
  • Randall K. Marquette was found guilty of Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal), an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 343.44(1)(b).
  • Randall K. Marquette was found guilty of Resisting or Obstructing an Officer [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).
  • Randall K. Marquette was found guilty of Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Repeater], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).
  • Randall K. Marquette was found guilty of Bail Jumping-Felony [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).
  • Randall K. Marquette was found guilty of Bail Jumping-Felony [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).
  • Randall K. Marquette was found guilty of Bail Jumping-Felony [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).
  • Randall K. Marquette was found guilty of Bail Jumping-Felony [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).
  • Randall K. Marquette was found guilty of Possession of THC (2nd+ Offense), a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(e).
  • Randall K. Marquette was found guilty of Resisting/Failing to Stop/Fleeing, an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 346.04(2t).
  • Randall K. Marquette was found guilty of Operating w/ PAC (5th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(b).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Defendant not to be eligible for Substance Abuse Program until after 11/21/15.

superMiscConds.notes:
Fines & costs totalling $3,514.00 ordered to run concurrently with prison sentence.
Absolute sobriety.
No Class B establishments.
SCRAM or similar type monitor.
Full time employment or 5 job searches per week.
No vehicle operations without a valid driver's license.
DNA sample if not alread provided.

Court reads instruction 158
Attorney Analysis

In chambers Court explains history of this case. Defendant is representing himself and stipulates to his prior OWI's.  DA indicates he has provided all discovery to the defendant on Monday.  Witnesses discussed.  Motion in limine regarding photo of squad window.  Squad video cannot be found or doesn't exist.  Exhibits #1 - JOC 06CF156 and Exhibit #2 driving record submitted.  9:15 a.m. in courtroom.  Jurors receive their first oath.  Voir dire.  Jurors chosen receive their second oath.  Recess at 10:25 a.m. reconvene at 10:38 a.m.  Opening instructions read.  Opening statements by DA Parker and defendant.  Testimony taken, exhibits marked, offered and received.  DA requests paraphernalia charge be dismissed, so ordered. Further testimony.  Closing arguments by DA and defendant. Instructions read.  Jury retires for deliberations at 5:07 p.m., reconvene at 6:05 p.m. with guilty verdicts on all counts.

Motion to dismiss blood test results.  Attny Singh makes his arguments and allows his client to speak.  Attny Parker has video regarding the blood draw.  Officer Jeff L. sworn and testifies.  Exhibit #1 - video, marked and played for the Court.  Attny Singh advises the Court that the defendant is not satisfied with his representation.  Defendant makes a statement.  Court advises that either has to accept Attny Singh or will be representing himself at trial as it will not be postponed again.  Direct continued. Exhibits #2 & 4 identified by witness.  Exhibits #1, 2 & 4 offered and received.  Cross exam by Attny Singh. Shane S. sworn and testifies for the State.  Exh #3 marked and identified by the witness.  Cross exam.  Defendant questions witness about ViVue and squad video's.  Dan C. sworn and testifies for the State.  There is a video of the squad which was never turned over to the DA.  Court advises that should be produced.  Cross-exam.  Street clothes for the defendant for trial.  Court denies the motion.

Defendant no longer wants his current attorney.  Discussions about attorneys, motions, responsibilities, maximums, etc. discussed with defendant.  Court questions Attny Weerts about another attorney being appointed.  He is unsure because of the defendant's prior contacts.  Court authorizes the withdrawal of Attny Jordan. Witnesses to be sequestered except arresting officer Jeff L.  Defendant needs street clothes.
